awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Dimensions US-BIOTA-Sao Paulo: Scales of biodiversity - Integrated studies of snake venom evolution and function across multiple levels of diversity
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will determine how key innovations within the venom system have contributed to diversification in the 2,500 species of advanced snakes. Venom is hypothesized to have been the key innovation initiating the evolutionary radiation of snake species by expanding feeding opportunities. This project will seek to determine the factors and traits that promoted that diversification, and will test for biases in the genetic pathways underlying rapid evolution in venoms between closely related species. The study includes the training of two postdoctoral researchers, and multiple high school, undergraduate, and graduate students at three major state universities in Ohio and Florida. The research will produce new data on venom chemistry and function, which may be useful for novel drug discovery and design.

Representative samples of diverse species from three families of venomous snakes will be collected in the United States, Central America, and Brazil to test for relationships between venom function and diversification rates. Venom complexity, composition, and enzymatic-activity profiles will be assayed to test the hypothesis that higher venom evolvability is a prerequisite for rapid evolutionary diversification. Six closely related species pairs with highly divergent venoms will be chosen for molecular assays to evaluate the genetic and protein changes responsible for rapid evolution of venom function. This work will unite diversification studies and the genetics of adaptation to provide an integrated perspective of how adaptations are built and how they affect diversification, leading to an understanding of how biodiversity originates across micro- to macroevolutionary levels.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding how species diversify within evolutionary lineages requires two insights: First, how key features of organisms impact the multiplication of species over evolutionarily long timescales, and second, how these key features diverge between pairs of species over shorter timescales.  Venom represents a key organismal feature that has played an important role in species diversification in snakes at both short and long timescales. The advanced snakes (superfamily Colubroidea) are comprised of more than 2,500 species, account for the majority of extant snake species including the front-fanged venomous families Viperidae and Elapidae and a diverse array of rear-fanged venomous species in the family Colubridae. This project involved a large-scale international collaboration between scientists in the US and Brazil to address the question of how do differences in venom arise between closely related species of venomous snakes and then how these differences translate into the diversification of  snake species over long time evolutionary timescales. Over long timescales our work has shown that venom complexity in snakes evolves in a previously unknown way namely in response to phylogenetic diversity in a community of prey eaten by snakes, likely reflecting divergence in the physiological targets of venom. This provides a new insight in how evolution occurs: specifically, the nature of a species community, rather than their richness alone, is an important feature in the evolution of complex traits in organisms. At  shorter timescales, our work showed that three evolutionary mechanisms (venom gene sequence evolution, gene duplication, and gene expression variation) all play roles in the evolution venom differences but that the relative importance of each mechanism differs between different types of snakes. This demonstrates that evolution operates in different ways to achieve the same functional goal in even among similar types of organisms with the same ecological “problem” to solve.

This project also achieved a series of broader impacts related to training of students, communication of research results to the scientific community, scientific outreach to the general public and the generation of new knowledge about animal venoms which could potentially be used for drug design. First, a large number of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows received training in a broad range of bioinformatics skills which is a widely sought skill set for research scientists being hired outside of academics in both the public and private sectors. This was achieved through interactions between researchers at different labs in the US and Brazil resulting in US students being exposed to a broader international research community. Second, multiple talks describing key results were delivered to a range of research meetings including the prestigious Gordon Conference on Venom Evolution, Function and Biomedical Applications. Third, outreach activities to educate the general public on snake venom and evolutionary biology in general were developed and displayed. Finally, data on the whole genomes of roughly 8 venomous snake species, and venom gland transcriptomes from 100’s of samples have been deposited in public databases providing an unprecedented expansion of data on animal toxins which could be used for prospecting for new drug targets.
